121 (27·8%; 95% CI 23·5–32·0) of 436 Ghanaian children were seropositive to yellow fever virus 2·3 years after vaccination ( figure 1). Among the large majority below the seropositivity threshold, we classified 51 (11·7%, 8·7–14·7) as borderline ( table 2). Combination of the positive and borderline strata resulted in 172 children (39·4%, 34·9–44; figure 1). As in Mali, the proportion of children with broad-sense seropositivity was much smaller than the overall proportion observed 4 weeks after vaccination (611 [72·7%] of 841 children tested) in a previous study of the same Ghanaian population.
